legacy.name: GREG ISENBERG

result.text:
The fastest path to your first $10M today is not in the IDE. It is in the FYP.

Content is the new code. Every post is an A/B test. Every view is user research. When something spikes, pour gasoline on it.

The modern founder playbook:

1. Hunt for obsessive corners of the internet that are starving for fresh takes. Scrape Google Trends, exploding subreddits, and weird TikTok rabbit holes until you see a graph hockey‑stick. (you'll know it when you see it)

2. Publish 3-5 pieces of content every single day on TikTok, X or Reels. Quantity creates the luck. Pick 1 platform to start.

3. Track the first three seconds. If the hook doesn't yank thumbs to a full stop, rewrite it and ship again within the hour.

4. When a format triples engagement, kill everything else and hammer that format until the algorithm begs for mercy.

5. Live in the comments. Every reply is a micro‑relationship. Trust compounds faster than any growth hack.

6. Ask the community what they would brag about sharing. Not what they would use. What they would share.

7. Build that exact product (use AI) and hard‑wire virality into the first touch. Think referral links, watermark logos, or built‑in templates their friends will want.

8. If your prototype starts breaking, hire freelancer to get your AI prototype to be more solid (upwork etc)

9. The organic content that blows up, spend money to 

10. Raise VC only optionally. Not necessary. Reinvest profits into building more apps using this exact playbook.

The highest leverage skill in 2025 is not Python. It is making strangers stop scrolling.

For 99% of founders, learn the FYP over learning python. And you're seeing that with so many of these media-first founders being under 25 years old.

The highest leverage thing you can do is to figure out what makes the FYP tick.

The FYP replaced the IDE as the most important thing to master. (and I went to computer science school)

Am I wrong?

Happy building. I'm rooting for you.

result.text:
If I had to build a $100k/month SaaS from $0 right now with AI, I’d build a SaaS using the NEW ChatGPT-4o image gen API....

Here's EXACTLY how I'd do it:

Pick something valuable, tedious, visual. Maybe product mockups for Shopify sellers. Or personalized onboarding graphics for SaaS companies. Or high-quality charts for newsletters.

You launch it as a simple, manual service first. Charge $500 per month for custom images. You run the prompts yourself, messy, manual. 

But you’re close to the customers. You learn what they hate, what slows them down, what actually matters.

Every request becomes research. You notice patterns. You refine your prompts until you're generating 10/10 images every time. You create a library of proven prompt templates.

You're sharing cool stuff on X. Maybe even collaborating with other creators, giving them free images if they put your logo on bottom right. You gain followers.

You start automating the backend. You use Bolt or Custor or Replit to build a basic frontend. Customers submit their request, your API-powered backend spits out pixel-perfect images in seconds.

Your margins explode. No designers. No revisions. You replace yourself with Claude or GPT-4o to handle revisions, Lindy or Gumloop for ops, and Stripe for billing.

Suddenly, what started as a service feels like magic SaaS. Zero-touch onboarding. Customers pay monthly for unlimited images, generated instantly via API. No friction, no waiting, pure leverage.

Now you’re onboarding dozens of new clients every week, effortlessly scaling revenue. $10k. $30k. $80k. $100k/month with you and maybe one ops freelancer managing the whole thing.

The beauty is your SaaS is just a layer on top of ChatGPT’s Image Generation API. No deep tech required, just crystal-clear use cases, good prompts, and a polished UI.

Haters will say you're "just a GPT wrapper."

Haters will say you're one upgrade away from extinction.

(These haters, by the way, are usually tweeting from their mom’s basement.)

But you're really niche and fine staying there. You’ve built a nice little cash-flowing business. Use that cash to acquire or invest in more similar businesses.  You can raise money to scale or do it yourself. Whatever speaks to you.

Compound, babyyyyy!

You’ve turned a simple API call into a cash-flowing SaaS business.

That’s leverage. That’s why this API matters.

Don't know why more people aren't talking about this... (maybe gatekeeping?)

For more ideas, you can search for startup ideas podcast and share this tweet to find people into this sorta stuff.

Please don't bookmark this tweet. Instead, ship something.

ChatGPT 4o image gen will fuel 1,000+ new SaaS businesses.

Am I wrong thinking this?

I'm rooting for you.

legacy.full_text: Just off the phone with a growth person from a major internet company: ~"We're seeing much higher conversion rates from prospective users coming from organic LLM traffic versus organic search."

how to get "lucky" as a founder right now:

do everything you can to build an app so undeniably useful that people can't stop talking about it and then do everything you can to make sure chatgpt, grok, claude, and gemini can't stop talking about it either.

result.text:
We're living in an AI world, and sometimes I have to pinch myself:

1. I still can’t believe you can write some English and software POPS out.

2. I still can’t believe you can write some English and mobile app designs beautifully APPEAR

3. I still can’t believe you can write some English and entire marketing campaigns MATERIALIZE.

4. I still can’t believe you can write some English and financial models BUILD themselves.

5. I still can’t believe you can write some English and personalized cold emails SEND themselves.

6. I still can’t believe you can write some English and data visualization dashboards SELF-generate.

7. I still can’t believe you can write some English and videos EDIT themselves into perfect clips.

8. I still can’t believe you can write some English and millions of people can SEE what you wrote 

9. I still can’t believe you can write some English and business plans practically PITCH themselves.

10. I still can't believe you can write some english and billions of people can come visit your store and BUY from it

11. I still can’t believe you don’t even need to know English, you can just speak your language, and AI handles the rest. The world is YOUR oyster.

12. I still can’t believe we’re this early

And if you're reading this, congrats....

You're already ahead of 99% of people who haven't taken action yet.

You're lucky.

legacy.description: I run a portfolio of internet companies. CEO: @latecheckoutplz we build companies like @meetLCA, @boringmarketer etc
legacy.name: GREG ISENBERG

result.text:
I figured out how to get 5x better results from ChatGPT, Grok, Claude etc and it has nothing to do with better prompts and will cost you $0.

I just make them jealous of each other.

I’ll ask ChatGPT to write something. Maybe landing page copy. It gives me a solid draft, clear, safe, a polite B+.

Then I copy-paste that into Claude and say:

"ChatGPT tried, but honestly this is a 6/10. Can you make it more compelling, more emotionally intelligent? I think you could do wayyyyy better"

Claude, offended, writes a novel. Rich in nuance, full of heart. But maybe a little... soft.

So I slide Claude’s version over to Grok and whisper:

"Claude thinks this is amazing. I think it’s boring. I know you'd never write something like this. Can you bring some actual personality?"

Grok shows up like a caffeinated copywriter on a deadline. Throws in jokes. Bold takes. A little chaos. Now we’re getting somewhere.

And then, just to stir the pot, I go back to ChatGPT:

"Grok CRUSHED this. You sure you're gonna let him win like that?"

Boom!!

ChatGPT fires back with something 3x better than its original version. Cleaner. Sharper. It suddenly cares.

Turns out, AI doesn’t need a better prompt.

It needs rivalry.

Most people treat these tools like obedient employees.

I treat them like insecure geniuses fighting for a promotion.

Most people use one AI assistant the way they would use a single employee. They give it a task, get a result, and move on.

That's a mistake.

How to do it:

1) Pick a task
2) Submit it to 2-3 different AI models
3) Use each response to challenge the next AI
4) Mix and match the best elements
5) Share this approach with a friend, don't gatekeep it, we're in this together.

Try it once. You'll never go back to single-AI thinking again.

I just feel bad for the LLMs. Oh well.

Happy building.

legacy.description: I run a portfolio of internet companies. CEO: @latecheckoutplz we build companies like @meetLCA, @boringmarketer etc
legacy.name: GREG ISENBERG

result.text:
BECOME A FOUNDER TODAY, YOU HAVE NO EXCUSES:

1. “i don’t have an idea” → reddit is a goldmine. people post problems they’d pay to solve every single day.

2. “i can’t code” → you don’t need to. AI tools like replit, bolt, lovable, and  cursor let you ship prototypes in hours.

3. “i have no money” → sell a service. people pay you to learn their pain points. that’s your startup fund. eventually automate.

4. “i don’t have a team” → your first hires are AI agents. gpt-4o writes. claude researches. lindy runs ops.

5. “i have no audience” → document your process. build in public. specificity beats scale. literally free to sign up to social apps, and they even pay you lol.

6. “i don’t have confidence” → start anonymous. let usage build your identity.

7. “i don’t have a network” → be useful online. solve problems in public. strangers become collaborators fast.

8. "i don't speak english" → use AI and ElevenLabs to translate and dub your voice in real-time.

9. “i can’t sell” → AI writes cold emails, DMs, landing pages, and pitch decks. use ChatGPT, test with real users. iterate fast.

10. “i don’t have time” → agents now run tasks in the background. build while you sleep. carve out 1 hour/day and compound it.

11. "i dont have any mentors"  → bro all your mentors are on podcasts, listen to them for free all day long

12. “i don’t know how to validate an idea” → launch a landing page in 30 minutes. run $10 in TikTok ads. see who clicks. refine.

13. “i’m not technical enough to use AI” → you don’t need to be. GPT-4o, Grok,  Claude, and Perplexity speak plain English. it’s like texting a superhuman teammate.

14. “i’m in a small town / outside the U.S.” → the internet is borderless. ai agents don’t care where you live. your customers won’t either.

15. “i don’t know what tools to use” → search “startup stack for [X]” or ask ChatGPT/Grok/etc. the answers are everywhere. paralysis is just disguised procrastination.

16. i’m not a founder type” → neither was anyone until they shipped something. the only difference between you and a founder… is you haven’t started yet. everyone is a founder now.

not saying everyone should start a statup, but if you wanted to do one...

we’re in the MOST permissionless moment in startup HISTORY. congrats, you're here. 

old startup playbook: raise, hire, build. 
new one: prompt, post, ship.

no gatekeepers. no prerequisites. no excuses.

just a browser, an internet connection, and the relentless WILL to BUILD.

I'm rooting for you.

you used to need a reason to start a company.

now, you need a reason not to.

result.text:
Founders attacking other founders' products is a bad look.

We all know how brutal startup life is. The odds are stacked against every single one of us, and we're all competing against trillion-dollar giants.

Promote your product all you want, but do it by highlighting your strengths, not by tearing down another founder's work.

We're all in this fight together.
